Line 100: Line 100:
==Musical treatment and recording==
==Musical treatment and recording==
  +
[[File:Me and Juliet 1953.jpg|right|cover of album]]
[[File:Rodgers.jpg|right|thumb|upright|alt=Photo of Rodgers in middle age, seated in a theatre, wearing a suit and holding a cigarette|Richard Rodgers]]
[[File:Rodgers.jpg|right|thumb|upright|alt=Photo of Rodgers in middle age, seated in a theatre, wearing a suit and holding a cigarette|Richard Rodgers]]
One source of Rodgers's excitement for the concept which became ''Me and Juliet'' was the opportunity to have a truly contemporary score, which might not be possible in an adaptation. At the time Rodgers wrote the score, there was a [[Latin dance]] craze in the United States, and its influence found its way into the score. Rodgers put an onstage jazz trio in the productionâand encouraged them to improvise. According to author and composer [[Ethan Mordden]], Rodgers's score "found R & H going for impish, nimble, the sound of the Hit Parade as reimagined by R & H".<ref name = "m152">Mordden, p. 152.</ref> Rodgers borrowed the music for "No Other Love" from his award-winning score for ''Victory at Sea''.<ref name = "h180"/>
One source of Rodgers's excitement for the concept which became ''Me and Juliet'' was the opportunity to have a truly contemporary score, which might not be possible in an adaptation. At the time Rodgers wrote the score, there was a [[Latin dance]] craze in the United States, and its influence found its way into the score. Rodgers put an onstage jazz trio in the productionâand encouraged them to improvise. According to author and composer [[Ethan Mordden]], Rodgers's score "found R & H going for impish, nimble, the sound of the Hit Parade as reimagined by R & H".<ref name = "m152">Mordden, p. 152.</ref> Rodgers borrowed the music for "No Other Love" from his award-winning score for ''Victory at Sea''.<ref name = "h180"/>
